$nvda $TWTR $TSLA  
If the markets collapsed in 2018, and the situation is arguably worse now, what will make the markets perform better this time? Rising oil prices, and a rising dollar, will dampen global growth prospects, which should reduce inflation 
 
more stress 
Much of the increase in oil prices is due to the war in Ukraine. However, the longer prices remain high, and at the same time countries lose purchasing power due to a strong dollar, the more difficult it is to maintain economic growth. We've already seen some of the effects of that - the International Monetary Fund recently lowered its full 2022 global growth forecast to 3.6%, down from more than 4 
 
These higher prices will slow growth even in the US, with higher prices and higher energy prices. Moreover, the effects of higher interest rates will also tighten financial conditions, reduce the amount of overall leverage in stock markets, and asset price expectations in general

$nvda $TWTR $TSLA  
An article I read and I wanted you to share your opinion on(The stock market may be close to breaking point) 
The last time mortgage rates were around 5%, the dollar index was above 97.50, the price of oil was above $75, and the 10-year bond yield was around 3%. It was in the fall of 2018 when the Fed was conducting quantitative tightening and an increase in interest rates, which is exactly what happened when the markets collapsed. 
The S&P 500 fell 20%, and the Fed was forced to hold back on its rate hike. He kept it at first and then had to cut interest rates and bring back quantitative easing by the fall of 2019.The last time the market broke 
Just four years later, we again have mortgage rates over 5%, the dollar index at 100, oil trading at over $100, and a 10-year bond yield close to 3%. Moreover, the Fed is now embarking on its largest rate-raising cycle and is very likely to conduct quantitative tightening at a faster pace than it did in 2018. 
(1-4)

$SPY Stock market is pretty funny.  When the market goes up, people think every company going to reach new highs.  When market goes down, it's the crash and every company going bankrupt.  Seriously, people thought $BA was going bankrupt but bounced nicely from 100 to 275 at one point.  $NFLX is the same, do you REALLY think Netflix is bigger risk than say $AAPL $NVDA with massive exposure to China?    If anything, Netflix has the biggest exposure to China that hasn't been monetized.   Figure that out and Netflix will be 700+ as billions illegal streamers add to subscribers.
